translated: Notes on the thirty-third fascicle of the YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi ÅšÄstra
The first fourth in the section on attaining fruits, the first in the section on attaining fruits through yoga
Spoken by Fu Hui, listened to by Sui
It is said that the two meditative absorptions are extensively distinguished.
It refers to the two meditative absorptions of signlessness and cessation. As for the five supernatural powers,

It refers to the fruits of the eight meditative absorptions such as the first meditative absorption, which are the fundamental stages of the eight meditative absorptions. As for the various characteristics,
It refers to being free from the desires of the two realms of form and non-form.
The above seven approaches are established based on the worldly path. As for contemplating the truths,
It refers to the four persons who practice the preparatory phase of the path of seeing. As for penetrating reality,
This is the stage of the path of seeing. As for extensively distinguishing cultivation,ğŸ”½This is the stage of cultivation. As for the ultimate being at the end,
This is the stage of post-learner. As for partially enjoying cessation,

It means those who first generate the mind, cultivate the seven contemplations, and are people who enjoy seeing and cultivating the two delusions of desire and form. It is said that they first cultivate. It is said that the first and so on.
It means that ordinary beings have not yet severed the two delusions of desire and form, and therefore they are not yet free from the bonds. It is said that the second and so on.

It means that those in training have already severed the delusions of desire and partially severed the delusions of form, and therefore they are not yet free from all bonds. It is said that this and so on.
It means that from the second concentration and above up to the sphere of nothingness, there are six. It is said that again, in the concentrations and so on.
It means that the eight concentrations such as the concentrations are the causes that can induce the two concentrations of cessation and the five supernatural powers as fruits.
It means the divine eye and so on. It is said that if one is born.
It means the sixth gate of distinctions in birth mentioned above. It is said that if it is a characteristic.
It means the seventh gate of characteristics of detachment mentioned above.
Here, the remaining four gates such as the eighth contemplation of the truths and so on are not listed.
This is because they are included in the cause and effect of the supramundane path. It is said that the skeleton.
This illustrates how the five desires are like dry bones.ğŸ”½Even if one eats them, there is no flavor, illustrating that there is no satisfaction.
As for congealed blood,ğŸ”½this illustrates that many people share in it, like a marketplace where there is a share in harming the multitude.
As for a grass torch,
this illustrates the meaning of the cause of evil conduct.ğŸ”½It means that if one holds a grass torch and does not discard it, one will surely burn one's hand.
As for a portion of charcoal fire,
this illustrates the growth of desire.ğŸ”½If one approaches a fire pit, one will not be able to quench one's thirst.
As for poisonous snakes,ğŸ”½this illustrates the meaning of being shunned by the wise.
As for what is seen in a dream,ğŸ”½this illustrates the meaning of quickly passing away and disappearing.
As for borrowed ornaments,ğŸ”½this illustrates the meaning of relying on many conditions.
As for like the top of a tree,
this illustrates the meaning of the six grounds of heedlessness.ğŸ”½It means that one who indulges in desires will surely fall into an evil realm.
As for such things,
The meanings of these eight metaphors are already extensively explained in the verses of the stage of contemplation.
Among the sixteen sentences,
the first eight sentences correspond one by one to the first eight metaphors.
The latter eight are based on impermanence, etc., to show the faults of desire.ğŸ”½As should be known according to the treatise.
It is said that this attention, etc.,
means that because the attention of understanding characteristics is the cause, the subsequent attention of resolve is born.ğŸ”½It is said that it is mixed,
which means that the attention of understanding characteristics is accomplished by the mixed cultivation of the two dharmas of hearing and contemplation. It is said that it is only used for practice.
This shows that the characteristics of the wisdom accomplished by cultivation rely on the initial meditation and take the initial meditation as the object. It is said that this resolve, etc.,
means that because the three resolves of the beginning, middle, and end are the causes, the subsequent attention of separation is accomplished.
Therefore, the treatise says, First arising, etc. It is said that the attention that accompanies it,
means that when cutting off the coarse characteristics and afflictions of the desire realm,
It is accompanied by attention.
The following five gates all take the preceding as the cause to accomplish the subsequent dharma. As for the various afflictions,
it refers to the obstacles to the practice in the first dhyÄna. As for the coarseness,
it refers to the nature of being without lightness and ease. As for the passage that begins with from this point onward,
it means that by the intention of being far removed, one cultivates the seven dharmas as the cause for giving rise to joy, which then becomes the accomplishment of being far removed.
First, one delights in cutting off.
Second, one delights in being far removed.
Third, one sees the superior merits within the various cut-offs.
Fourth, one touches and experiences a small portion.
This means that because one initially attains the joy of being free from birth,
fifth, from time to time one delights in the intention.
Sixth, from time to time one is disgusted with the intention.
Seventh, in order to eliminate the five obstacles of the first dhyÄna,
therefore the treatise says in order to eliminate and send away, etc. As for the passage that begins with habitually being close to,
it refers to the three minds of beginning, middle, and end.
Because in the first dhyÄna, one is still unable to eliminate the various habitual tendencies that are obstacles.
When one sees pure and beautiful colors, one gives rise to false thoughts.
Therefore, the treatise says that one is unable to abandon them, etc. The term various activities
refers to the various activities such as form, etc. The phrase this is due to temporary, etc.
Here there is a difficulty.
In this way, the first dhyÄna samÄdhi eliminates the coarse characteristics of the desire realm.
Is it able to suddenly eliminate the seeds from long ago?
Or is it only able to eliminate the present activities?
Therefore, the treatise answers, This is due to temporary, etc. The phrase again, in terms of far-reaching separation, etc.
Here there is a question.
Among the seven mental orientations, why only clarify the four of far-reaching separation, etc., speaking of the characteristics of having the experience of joy?
Why not speak of the remaining three?
The answer is:

Because the three mental orientations of ascertaining characteristics, ascertaining understanding, and ascertaining observation are said to be without the stage of samÄdhi in the scattered state, they are unable to give rise to joy. The phrase without any gaps means:
It is said that from the end of receiving [the precepts] up to the present, the joy and pleasure of separation are uninterrupted. As for the five factors,
first, investigation;
second, analysis;
third, joy;
fourth, pleasure;
fifth, one-pointedness of mind. As for abiding in the desire realm, etc.,
it is said that one is able to counteract the coarse characteristics of the desire realm and is able to cultivate and realize the fruit of the first dhyÄna.
There is a question here.
Among the seven types of attention, why is only the attention of discerning characteristics explained?
It is said that the five desires should be eliminated and the first dhyÄna should be attained. As for being able to observe what has been attained, etc.,

if one does not contemplate, one will give rise to the notion of attainment with regard to what has not been attained, and this is called excessive pride. As for also discerning characteristics, etc.,
it is said that these two dharmas are generally able to follow and turn away from the five desires and cultivate the antidotes. As for being like this, etc.,
if one relies on the Tibetan text, it says:
It should be known that these six types of attention are included within the four types of attention.
The meaning of this is explained as follows:
Excluding the preparatory, final, and resultant mental activities.

The remaining six are all mental activities of the causal stage, and are therefore included in the four dharmas of following, etc. The phrase in the place where they are located meansğŸ”½in the first trance state.
The coarse characteristics of the first trance state
are the characteristics of purity of the second trance state. The clear observation of the meaning of dependence
should be understood according to the previous three principles. The phrase should be understood as before means
that just as the mental activity of understanding characteristics is found throughout the first trance state,
the six such as resolve are also found throughout.ğŸ”½Therefore, they are as explained above. The phrase the first trance state
and the phrase Furthermore, this...
If based on the Tibetan text,
first the sÅ«tra passage is indicated,
and then it is explained.
This intermediate sÅ«tra passage
should be known by the expounder. The phrase sÅ«tra passage
means the sÅ«tra says:
The first trance state is called the separation from desires, evil and unwholesome dharmas,
with investigation, with reflection, and the joy and pleasure born of separation.
In the first dhyÄna, one abides in perfect tranquility. As for the desire for afflictions,
it refers to the mutual love and attachment between men and women. As for the desire for objects,
it refers to the greed for wealth and treasures, etc. As for being separated from being conjoined,
it refers to being separated from the five desires and the meaning of being conjoined. As for being separated from objects,
it refers to the five desirable objects. As for afflictions,
it refers to the desire for afflictions. As for desire,
it refers to the desire for objects. As for taking this as the cause,ğŸ”½it refers to taking the intention of finalizing the practice as the cause. As for what is cultivated,
it refers to the accomplishment of the fruition of finalizing the practice. As for attaining what one wishes for,
it refers to attaining mastery over going out and coming in, etc. As for difficulty,
it refers to being able to be conjoined with samÄdhi with little cultivation. As for being rough,
keng means brief.

It means that without effort, one can remain in samÄdhi for the entire night. The mind that is in accordance with this and the other three minds each correspond to it. It says according to one's desire.
It means that one who has attained samÄdhi in the desire realm can emerge from samÄdhi after seven days. It says Furthermore, in the presence of vitarka, etc.
If one relies on the Tibetan text,
these four dhyÄnas each first cite the sÅ«tra passage,
and then explain it.
It says that both the MahÄyÄna and HÄ«nayÄna sÅ«tras say:
The second dhyÄna is because the search and investigation are tranquil,
internally tranquil,
with the mind going in one direction,
giving rise to samÄdhi, joy, and pleasure.
One fully abides in the second dhyÄna. It says accomplishing this and that, etc.
The sÅ«tra says:
It says 'the third dhyÄna is.'
Relying on this separation from desires, abiding in equanimity, with right mindfulness and right knowledge, experiencing bodily pleasure,
the sages proclaim the complete endowment of equanimity, mindfulness, and right knowledge.
Abiding in the bliss of the body, relying on the absence of joy.

translated: Fully abiding in the third dhyÄna.

The meaning is explained in the treatise. The so-called joy is the second distracted mind. The so-called mind contrary to joy is the feeling of equanimity. The so-called physical body is the five sense organs of form. The so-called mind is the mind faculty. The so-called third dhyÄna and above, etc. these two gates manifest and explain all the causes. The so-called lower stages are below the second dhyÄna. The so-called higher stages are above the fourth dhyÄna. The so-called noble ones are the Buddha and his noble disciples, etc. If in the original text here there is the separation from joy and the full abiding in the third dhyÄna, the explanation of the meaning is the same as before, so the translator does not bring it out. The speaker should know. The so-called and so forth, etc. here there is a difficulty.
Why does the sutra only speak of the cessation of pleasure in the fourth dhyana, and not of its antidotes?
Therefore the treatise answers, Here, the antidotes, etc.
That is to say, the cessation of pleasure as an antidote is similar to the cessation of investigation, analysis, and joy as antidotes mentioned earlier.
Therefore it is not mentioned.
Here, the sutra passage should be stated first.
Therefore the sutra says:
As for the fourth dhyana,
because pleasure is ceased,
because suffering is ceased,
and because joy and sorrow have previously disappeared,
at that time, neither suffering nor pleasure, with equanimity and mindfulness purified,
one fully abides in the fourth dhyana.
The explanation of the meaning is as follows. As for what has been previously ceased,
it refers to the feelings of joy, sorrow, and suffering. As for what is now ceased,
it refers to the feeling of pleasure that is ceased in the fourth dhyana. As for now relying on this, etc.,
there is a question here.
If the fourth dhyana ceases the feeling of pleasure,
Why does the sÅ«tra say that in the fourth dhyÄna, suffering, joy, and worry are also eliminated?
Therefore, the treatise answers, Now, in this [fourth dhyÄna], it is the same.
Although eliminating suffering and pleasure is called the feeling of equanimity,
because joy and worry are eliminated in the first, second, and third dhyÄnas,
they are collectively referred to as being eliminated in the fourth dhyÄna. As for blue, yellow, red, white, etc.,
this refers to the forms in the desire realm and form realm. As for free from desire,
it means being disgusted with the desires of the form realm.
If in the original text, the sÅ«tra passage should also be stated first.
The sÅ«tra says:
As for the sphere of infinite space,
it transcends the characteristics of form.
The characteristics of resistance are extinguished.
The various characteristics are not attended to.
One enters into infinite space.
One fully abides in the sphere of infinite space. As for many kinds,
it means that in the desire realm and form realm, blue, yellow, etc. are all due to shape, appearance, and combination.
It is able to obstruct the formless realm. As for due to the abandonment of form and the exhaustion of perceptions of multiplicity,ğŸ”½although there is no food and drink, etc.
in the form realm,
there are still palaces, clothing, and ornaments.
Therefore, it is said to be equal in appearance. As for Furthermore, if it is due to,
the sutra says:
The sphere of infinite consciousnessğŸ”½means transcending all the sphere of infinite space and entering the sphere of infinite consciousness.
One fully abides in the sphere of infinite consciousness. As for Furthermore, from the sphere of infinite consciousness,
the sutra says:ğŸ”½The sphere of nothingness
means transcending all the sphere of infinite consciousness and entering the sphere of nothingness.
One fully abides in the sphere of nothingness.
This means that due to the cause of being disgusted with the sphere of infinite consciousness,
one gives rise to superior understanding in the sphere of nothingness. As for Or form,
it refers to the aggregate of form. As for not form,
it refers to the other four aggregates. As for all existents,
It means that in the previous dhyÄnas there are characteristics and no characteristics, not without characteristics, because the characteristics cannot be obtained.
Therefore, the treatise says not having characteristics, etc. The phrase not like non-existence, etc.
Means that in these two samÄdhis, in all minds, the samÄdhi of no characteristics eliminates the first six consciousnesses.
If the samÄdhi of cessation has two kinds.
If a non-returner enters it, the seventh consciousness is eliminated below.
If an arhat enters it, the eighth consciousness is eliminated. The phrase like honey in a beehive
Means that like bees, it is difficult to obtain the honey in the hive.
The supramundane samÄdhi is also like this.
Therefore, the Tibetan text says:
The body sinks into the ground. The phrase and so on
Means that the samÄdhi of no characteristics can be entered based on the four dhyÄnas.
If the samÄdhi of cessation can be entered based on the four formless concentrations. The phrase temporarily ceasing and so on
Means that seeing and conceptualization, the two dharmas, disturb the body and mind, so they are temporarily ceased. The phrase object
It refers to the two dharmas of conceptualization and feeling. As for not thinking and intention,
It refers to not thinking about conceptualization. As for in the state of mind,
It refers to when cultivating the six intentions such as the characteristics of conceptualization and so forth,
All have the sixth mental consciousness. As for the mind no longer turns,
It refers to the time of the seventh stage of final fruition of practice. As for the cessation of mind and mental factors,
It refers to the sixth mental consciousness and below, the mind and its associated factors no longer functioning. As for the fundamental,
It refers to the intention of the final fruition of practice that has already attained the four meditations. As for understanding the meaning of dependence,
It refers to the principles of the five supernatural powers. As for understanding the Dharma of dependence,
It refers to understanding the causal Dharma of the five supernatural powers. As for sometimes,
It refers to those with dull faculties who cultivate the twelve characteristics such as lightness and so forth in this life,
And in later lives they are able to give rise to the five supernatural powers. As for having a portion,
It means that those of sharp faculties who cultivate in this life can give rise to the five supernatural powers. As for this thought,
it means that by lightness and agility one gives rise to the thought of the superior understanding of lightness and agility in the body.
The meanings of the next nine sections are all the same as this. As for well-trained,
it means silk is well-trained. As for and so on,
it means that just as earth and water transform into the other elements, wind and fire transform into transformations, and the superior understanding should be known as such.
Therefore, the treatise says and so on. As for or with the body,
it means by accomplishing the characteristics of the space element. As for or in the earth,
it is because of the characteristics of softness and lightness that are accomplished. As for or in the vast,
it is because of the accomplishment of the body and mind being in accord with each other. As for according to what is appropriate,
the above four characteristics are combined one by one.
It means that because of the superior understanding of the characteristics of the space element being accepted,
one can directly pass through walls and other obstacles without obstruction.
The rest are all similar to this. As for a part,

it means that from the desire realm up to the intermediate state between the first dhyÄna and the second dhyÄna, there is only the form created by ghosts and spirits that cannot obstruct. As for because of this,
it means because of the accomplishment of the characteristics of recollection.
One can know the coarse aspects of one's own activities from birth to old age within the gate of non-loss of sequence.
One is unable to recollect the subtle aspects.
It means both the coarse and subtle of the worldly path can be recalled.
This reveals the supernormal knowledge of past abodes. As for again, the various,
it means the good, bad, etc. karma possessed by sentient beings in the five destinies that can induce the function of good and bad fruits.
One is able to clearly know.
This is also called the characteristic of light. As for always changing color,
it means when angry, if one accidentally touches another person, one's facial expression changes. As for explaining in detail up to,
it means the various changes in the practices of greed, etc. of sentient beings.
It is called the supernormal knowledge of others' minds. As for the supernormal knowledge of transforming things,
It means transforming earth into water, etc. As for the supernormal knowledge of creating things,
It means manifesting existence in the midst of non-existence. As for the supernormal knowledge of resolve,
It means transforming little into much, etc. As for the supernormal knowledge of no conflict,
It refers to the samadhi of no conflict.
It is called the supernormal knowledge of aspiration because it attracts sentient beings.
It is called the supernormal knowledge of vows because it is the vast practice of vows.
The remaining text can be seen. As for the holy ones, etc.,
Although the supernormal knowledge of spiritual powers is mentioned here,
The five spiritual powers all have distinctions. As for all being able to accomplish,
It means the five characteristics are able to accomplish the supernormal knowledge of spiritual powers.
The remaining five all have accomplishment.
As previously explained. As for mixed cultivation,
It means cultivating both the worldly and supramundane paths together. As for if it is a place,
Among the three grades, the sphere of space and the sphere of consciousness are combined as the lower grade.
The remaining two are medium and superior. As for by those gods, etc.,
There is a question here.
Do the four formless concentrations have a location or not?
Therefore, the treatise answers, They have no form or shape, etc.
Although they have no location,ğŸ”½they are simply named according to the distinctions of the emptiness, consciousness, etc. that are the basis of their function.
As for the phrase the lower, middle, and upper grades within this,
it means that because these five grades are the causes, one attains the five pure abode heavens.
